In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and may Allah bless our Prophet Muhammad and all his family and companions.
To proceed...
This is the book of Al-Khallal, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, in which he mentioned Hadiths and Athar (narrations) from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, and the Tabi'in (Successors) and those who came after them regarding the encouragement to earn a livelihood and the prohibition of asking (begging) from people.
In it, he refuted the Sufis, ascetics, and worshipers who deviated from the guidance of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the guidance of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, in understanding the reality of what Allah sent His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, with, regarding his encouragement to earn and seek provision, and his warning against asking people.
The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, took a pledge from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, that they would not ask people for anything (1). And there is no Prophet among the Prophets except that he says to his people: {And I do not ask you for it any payment. My payment is only from the Lord of the worlds} [Ash-Shu'ara: 145]. So they do not ask people for wages or money, but rather they ask them for guidance.
Sects have deviated in this understanding. Among them are those who took the path of consuming people's wealth unjustly in the form of donations and charities, as Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, indeed many of the scholars and the monks devour the wealth of people unjustly and avert [them] from the way of Allah} [At-Tawbah: 34]. ...Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, said in the interpretation of this verse: "Thus it becomes clear that many of the scholars, monks, learned men, and worshipers consume people's wealth unjustly and avert from the way of Allah. And that the scholar who holds beliefs in issues of report and knowledge, and the worshiper who worships for himself, if they do not follow the legislated path, otherwise each of them is following his own desire" (1). For this reason, Sufyan bin Uyaynah said: "They used to say: Whoever becomes corrupt among our scholars has a resemblance to the Jews, and whoever becomes corrupt among our worshipers has a resemblance to the Christians" (2).
Therefore, you find many of these political Islamic movement groups competing in collecting charities. They have issued invalid fatwas; some allow investment of Zakat, some allow paying Zakat for elections, some allow building mosques and schools with Zakat funds, and there are scholars who wait for their financial percentage from the collection of charities.
Among those groups are people who took the path of seeking knowledge and abandoned seeking livelihood, thinking that seeking livelihood contradicts seeking knowledge, or that it is a deficiency in the description of a student of knowledge, or they believe they have a right to people's money, so they wait for someone to give them charity. These are most similar to the Sufi worshipers. Whoever looks at the state of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, knows the invalidity of what these people are upon.

Here is the inspired narrator (Muhaddith), the Commander of the Faithful, Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, taking turns with an Ansari in seeking livelihood (1). And here is Abdur-Rahman bin Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, who is one of the Ten Promised Paradise, saying: "Show me the way to the market" (2).
Whoever adopts the Sunnah of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and is guided by the guidance of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, in seeking livelihood and trade, Allah Almighty will make him independent of what is in people's hands.
Our Sheikh Muhammad Al-Anjari, may Allah preserve him and grant him success in all good, has great efforts in highlighting this subject, and he has an explanation of this treatise. We ask Allah Almighty to enrich us with His lawful provision over His prohibited, and with His bounty over anyone else, and to enlighten us in the matter of our religion, and guide us to His straight path.

13 - Muhammad bin Abi Harun (1) informed me that Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Hani told them, saying: Abu Abd Allah, may Allah have mercy on him, said to me: «Little wealth, you improve it so it remains (2), and much does not remain with corruption.»
14 - Harun bin Ziyad (3) informed us, Ibn Abi Umar told us, Sufyan told us, from Mis'ar, from Sa'd bin Ibrahim, from Hamid bin Abdul Rahman, that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: «Clumsiness in livelihood is more feared by me for you than poverty. Nothing decreases with improvement, and nothing remains with (4) corruption» (5).
15 - Harb bin Ismail informed me, Al-Musayyib bin Wadih told us, saying: Ash'ath (6) - meaning Ibn Shu'ba - said: I said to Ibrahim bin Adham: "I hire myself out in the market and I miss the prayer in congregation." He said: «Hire yourself out for a time (7), and be independent of people, and pray the prayers on time.»
foot_note:
1. He is Muhammad bin Musa bin Yunus. See his biography in Tarikh Baghdad (4/393).
2. Dropped from (Z).
3. He is Harun bin Yusuf bin Harun bin Ziyad Abu Ahmad known as Ibn Miqrad Al-Shatwi. See Tarikh Baghdad (16/43), and Tahdhib al-Kamal in the biography of Muhammad bin Yahya bin Abi Umar, among those who narrated from him.
4. In Original: On.
5. Its chain is weak, Hamid bin Abdul Rahman did not hear from Umar. See Tahdhib al-Tahdhib (3/45).
6. In Berlin copy: Ash'arna bin Al-Musha'ath. In Awqaf and King Saud copies: Ash'ath bin Shu'aib.
7. In (Z) copy: Misr, and established from other copies.

16 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, saying: I heard Abu Ja'far Al-Khurasani (1) say: I heard Shu'aib say: I said to Sufyan Al-Thawri: "What do you say about a man who is a bleacher/fuller, if he earns a dirham - in the dirham is what sustains him and sustains his dependents - he does not catch the prayer in congregation. But if he earns four daniqs (fractions of a dirham), he catches the prayer in congregation, but there isn't in the four daniqs what sustains him and sustains (2) his dependents. Which of them is better?" He said: «He earns the dirham and prays alone is better» (3).
17 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed me, saying: I said to Abu Abd Allah: "For what did Sufyan Al-Thawri go out to Yemen?" He said: «He went out for trade and to meet Ma'mar.» They said: "He had one hundred dinars." He said: «As for seventy, it is correct» (4).
18 - Yahya bin Abi Talib Al-Antaki (5) informed us, Al-Musayyib bin Wadih told us, saying: Yusuf bin Asbat said to me: «Sufyan Al-Thawri died and left two hundred dinars.» I said to him: "And from where did he have two hundred dinars when he was (6) the ascetic of scholars?"
foot_note:
1. He is Muhammad bin Harun bin Ibrahim. Al-Marrudhi explicitly mentioned his name in his book Akhbar Al-Shuyukh. See his biography in Tahdhib al-Kamal.
2. In Berlin copy: Remainder.
3. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilya (7/16), and Al-Dinawari in Al-Mujalasah (2952) with an addition at the end: .. and praying alone is better so that he does not waste his dependents. End quote. Abu Nu'aym narrated in Al-Hilya (7/15) from Sufyan Al-Thawri that he said regarding His saying {Trade and sale do not divert them from the remembrance of Allah} the verse: They used to buy and sell and not leave the prescribed prayers in congregation. Al-Bayhaqi narrated in Al-Zuhd Al-Kabir (938) from Sufyan Al-Thawri that he said to Shu'aib bin Harb: Look at your dirham, where is it from? And pray in the last row.
4. Mentioned by Al-Marrudhi in Al-Wara' (77).
5. The Baghdadi originally from Wasit, see his biography in Tarikh Baghdad (16/323). It appeared in the two printed versions and other copies except (Z) copy: Yahya bin Talib.
6. Dropped from (Z).

19 - Muhammad bin Amr bin Mukarram informed me, saying: I heard Abu Al-Hasan Al-Zahid say: A man said to Sufyan bin Uyaynah: "Can a man be an ascetic while having one hundred dinars?" He said: «Yes.» He said: "How is that?" He said: «If it decreases, he does not grieve (3), and if it increases, he does not rejoice, and he does not hate death because of parting with it» (4).
20 - Ali bin Al-Hasan (5) bin Harun informed me, Muhammad Al-Attar (6) told me, saying: And Hussein bin Ali bin Al-Aswad mentioned, from Ubaidullah (7) bin Musa, saying: I heard Sufyan Al-Thawri say: «Money in this time is a weapon» (8).
21 - Al-Hasan (9) bin Abdul Wahhab informed me, Abu Bakr - meaning Ibn
foot_note:
1. In Berlin copy: Make.
2. From Dawud bin Abi Hind, he said: I said to Al-Hasan: A man spends on his family an expenditure, if he wished he could suffice with less? He said: O man, expand upon yourself as Allah has expanded upon you. Al-Hasan also said: The people of heaven and earth do not know what Allah rewards the servant for the thing with which he brings joy to his dependents, family, and child. Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Kitab al-Iyal (2/557).
3. Established from (Z), and in other copies: Worry.
4. See Kitab al-Tawakkul by Abu Ya'la (p. 39).
5. In the two printed editions: Al-Hussein. See his biography in Tarikh Baghdad (13/311).
6. In (Z): Muhammad bin Muhammad Al-Attar, and likewise in the two editions. Established from other copies: Muhammad Al-Attar. He is Muhammad bin Saeed Al-Attar. See his biography in Tahdhib al-Kamal.
7. Established from (Z), and in Berlin and Awqaf copies: Abdullah.
8. Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Islah al-Mal (79) from Ubaidullah bin Musa with it.

Hammad Al-Muqri, told us, Ahmad bin Yaqub told us, Abu Al-Fath told us, saying: «Sufyan criticized those who do not see [the necessity of] work.» He said: «And Abu Bakr - meaning Al-Siddiq - saw a young man begging, so he hired him for himself.»
22 - Ahmad bin Mansur Al-Ramadi informed us, Abdul Razzaq told us, Muhammad bin Thawr told us, saying: Sufyan Al-Thawri used to pass by us while we were sitting in the Sacred Mosque, and say: «What makes you sit?» We would say: "So what should we do?" He said: «Seek from the bounty of Allah, and do not be dependents on the Muslims (1)» (2).
23 - Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal, may Allah be pleased with them both, told us, saying: Muhanna told me: Abu Hazim, a Sheikh who was with us in Akka, told me, saying: Sufyan Al-Thawri said: «Seeking knowledge is obligatory upon a man if he has a handful of food» (3). And I heard Muhammad bin Ishaq mention from Abdullah bin Saeed (4), from Ibn Abi Ghaniyah (5), from Sufyan Al-Thawri saying: «If you have wheat, then worship; otherwise seek it - meaning from its lawful source.»
foot_note:
1. In Berlin copy: People.
2. Narrated by Al-Dinawari in Al-Mujalasah (1082), and Al-Bayhaqi in Shu'ab al-Iman (9/221). In Musnad Ibn al-Ja'd (1921): Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: O readers (scholars), raise your heads for the path has become clear, race towards good deeds, and do not be dependents on Muslims.
3. Al-Khatib narrated in Al-Jami' li Akhlaq al-Rawi (50) from Ubaid bin Janad, saying to the people of Hadith: A man should know where his food, clothing, and housing come from, and such and such, then seek knowledge.
4. In (Z): Abi Saeed.
5. He is Yahya bin Abdul Malik bin Humaid. And it appeared in the two printed versions: Abdullah bin Abi Saeed from Ibn Abi Utbah. Both are misspellings.

24 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, saying: I heard Abu Ja'far Al-Khurasani, Abu Salih told us, saying: I heard Yusuf bin Asbat say to Shu'aib bin Harb: «Did you feel that seeking the Halal (lawful) is an obligation?» He said: «Yes» (1).
25 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, from Abu Abd Allah (2), from Abu Ja'far Al-Hadhdha' (3), from Shu'aib bin Harb, saying: «Do not despise a penny through the earning of which Allah is obeyed. It is not the penny that is intended, it is only obedience that is intended. Perhaps you buy herbs with it, and it does not settle in your stomach until you are forgiven» (4).
26 - Muhammad bin Abdul Samad Al-Muqri (5) informed me, Yusuf bin Muslim told us, saying: I heard Ali bin Bakkar say: «Ibrahim bin Adham used to hire himself out, and Sulaiman Al-Khawwas used to glean/scavenge, and Hudhayfa used to make bricks.»
27 - Ahmad bin Al-Faraj Abu Utbah (6) Al-Himsi informed us, Baqiyyah told us, saying: «If it was said to Ibrahim bin Adham: How are you? He said: Good, as long as no one bears my burden» (7).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in Hilyat al-Awliya (8/242). In Al-Adab Al-Shar'iyyah (3/277): Imam Ahmad was asked what softens the heart? He said: Eating Halal.
2. Established from (Z), and in other copies: Abi Abdan.
3. He is Muhammad bin Abdullah Abu Ja'far Al-Hadhdha' Al-Anbari. See his biography in Tarikh Baghdad (3/414).
4. Narrated by Al-Marrudhi in Kitab al-Wara' (83).
5. In the two printed editions: Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Abdul Samad. This is an error. He is Al-Massisi, one of Al-Khallal's teachers, he narrated from him in Kitab al-Sunnah and Risalat al-Amr bil Ma'ruf.
6. In Berlin copy: Abu Abdul Rahman. Established from other copies.
7. Narrated by Ibn Asakir in Tarikh Dimashq (6/342).

28 - Harb bin Ismail informed us, Al-Musayyib bin Wadih told us, saying: Ash'ath bin Shu'ba (1) told us, from Ibrahim bin Adham that he said to some of his brothers: «Do not leave working (profession), for if you work you are busy (occupied), and if you do not work you are known (exposed).»
29 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Al-Qasim Al-Azdi informed us, Tahir bin Muhammad Al-Tamimi told us, Al-Fayd bin Ishaq told us, saying: I asked Al-Fudayl bin Iyad, saying: "If a man sat in his house, claiming he trusts in Allah so his provision comes to him?" He said: «He means if he trusts in Him until he knows that he has trusted in Him, nothing he wanted would be prevented from him. But the Prophets and others did not do this. The Prophets used to hire themselves out, and the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, hired himself out, and Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them. They did not say: We sit until Allah Almighty provides. And Allah has said in His Book: {And seek from the bounty of Allah} (2), and there is no escape from seeking livelihood» (3).
30 - Umar bin Ali informed me, Harun bin Sufyan Al-Mustamli told us, saying: I heard Aswad bin Salim say: «Buy and sell even at capital price (without profit)» (4).
31 - Abdul Malik Al-Maymuni informed me, Abu Al-Abbas the companion of Abu Utbah (5) told me, saying: I asked Bishr bin Al-Harith about earning. He said: «Yes, by my life.» He said: As if he was saying: I do not see otherwise. And he said: «A human should
foot_note:
1. In Berlin copy: Sha'ath bin Al-Sha'tha. In Awqaf copy: Ash'ath bin Shu'aib.
2. In Berlin copy: {So seek provision from Allah}.
3. Al-Tabarani narrated in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir (6/219) from Salman, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Indeed, the soul, if it secures its provision, becomes reassured, free for worship, and whispers despair from it.
4. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in Hilyat al-Awliya (8/364).
5. Established from (Z), in other copies: Abu Uqbah.

look into his earnings, his food, and his dwelling. A human should investigate (1) his trade.» Then he said: «And were it not that I have no dependents, I would have worked and earned» (2).
32 - Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Khalid Al-Barathi (3) informed us, saying: Bishr bin Al-Harith said to me when he was informed of what was spent on us from our father's inheritance: «What was spent on you from this money has saddened me (4). You must be gentle and economical in spending. For you to spend the night hungry while you have money is more pleasing to me than to spend the night full while you have no money.» And Bishr said to me, connected to his speech and his questions (5): «It has reached me that you do not stick to the market, so stick to the market.» Then talk circulated between me and him, so he repeated to me: «Stick to the market even if you do not.» It fell into my heart: He meant: even if you do not profit. And he said to me: «Read my greetings to your mother and say to her: You must be gentle and economical in spending» (6).
33 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed me, saying: I heard some of the Sheikhs say: I heard Abu Yusuf Al-Ghasuli say: «Twelve dirhams suffice me for the year, a dirham every month. And nothing drives me to work except the tongues of these reciters (worshipers) saying: Abu Yusuf, where does he eat from?» (7).
foot_note:
1. Established from (Z), in other copies: Trade.
2. Al-Hasan Al-Basri said: The one who restricts his dependents is a traitor. Ayyub said: If I knew that my dependents needed a bundle of herbs, I would not sit with you. Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Kitab al-Iyal (2/547).
3. See his biography in Siyar A'lam al-Nubala (14/92).
4. In the margin of (Z) appended from the hearing of Al-Tayuri, and it is present in the Original.
5. In Original: His questioning.
6. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym (8/340).
7. In Shu'ab al-Iman (2/453) from Sufyan, he said: It was said to Ibn Al-A'rabi: Do you love Dirhams? He said: They benefit me and protect me.

34 - And Abu Bakr informed me, saying: I heard Harami bin Yunus (1) say: I heard Abu Yusuf Al-Ghasuli say: «I have been learning Fiqh regarding my food for sixty years» (2).
35 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed me, saying: I heard Ishaq bin Dawud say: I heard Al-Hasan bin Al-Rabi' say: «To earn a Qirat (small fraction) is more beloved to me than someone (3) giving me ten dirhams.»
36 - And Abu Bakr informed me, saying: I heard Muhammad bin Muqatil say: «A man should look at his loaf (4); where is it from? And look at his dirham; where is it from? Sufyan said: Do the deeds of heroes; meaning earning Halal» (5).
37 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us that he read to Abu Abd Allah, may Allah have mercy on him: Ibn Mahdi (6), from Sufyan, from

He has a biography in Tahdhib al-Kamal, and Tabaqat Al-Hanabila (1/404). Ibn Al-Jawzi quoted the narration in Sifat al-Safwa (4/277).
2. In Al-Zuhd Al-Kabir by Al-Bayhaqi (914), Yunus bin Ubaid said: Nothing is more precious than two things: A good (pure) dirham, and a man who acts upon Sunnah.

6. In Berlin copy: That he read to Ali bin Abdullah bin Mahdi. In Awqaf copy: That he read to Ibn Abdullah bin Mahdi. In King University copy: That he read to Abu Abdullah bin Mahdi. All are misspellings.

Amr bin Qais, from Asim, from Abu Wa'il, who said: «A dirham from trade is more beloved to me than ten from my stipend» (1).
38 - Harb informed me, he said Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman Al-Ju'fi told us, Abu Usama told us, from Yazid bin Ibrahim Al-Tustari, from Al-Hasan who said: «Two foods are good: A man carrying on his back, and his work with his hand» (2).
39 - Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Mahdi (3) informed me, Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Rabi'ah (4) told us, Ibn Al-Mubarak (5) told us, Sufyan told us, from Amr bin Qais, from Asim bin Abi Al-Nujud, from Abu Wa'il this Hadith.
40 - And Muhammad informed us, saying Waki' informed us, from Sufyan, from Amr bin Qais, from Asim bin Abi Al-Nujud, from Abu Wa'il, who said: «A dirham from trade is more beloved to me than ten from my stipend (6).»
41 - Al-Hasan bin Arafa informed us, saying: Qudama bin Shihab Al-Mazini Al-Basri told me, from Ismail bin Abi Khalid, from Wabrah, from Ibn Umar (7)
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (7/556), Ibn Sa'd in Al-Tabaqat (8/221), and Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Islah al-Mal [Encyclopedia of Imam Ibn Abi Al-Dunya] (7/454) with the wording: (from gifts) instead of (my stipend).
2. Narrated by Ahmad in Al-Zuhd (1552).
3. He is Abu Bakr Al-Massisi. See Tarikh Dimashq (5/70).
4. Established from (Z), and in other copies: Rabi'ah told us. This is an error, he is Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Rabi'ah bin Qudama Al-Qudami Al-Massisi. See Mizan al-I'tidal (2/488).
5. Established from (Z), and dropped from other copies.
6. In (Z): Giving.
7. In Berlin copy: From Wabrah bin Amr.

He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked about the best earning, so he said: «A man's work with his hand and every righteous sale» (1).
42 - Ahmad bin Al-Faraj Abu Utbah Al-Himsi informed me, saying Baqiyyah told us, from Shu'ba, from Al-Hakam. And Ahmad (2) told us, Al-Hasan (3) informed us, Yahya bin Adam (4) told us, saying Abdul Salam and Ibn Al-Mubarak told us, from Shu'ba, from Al-Hakam, from Mujahid regarding His saying: «Eat from the good things We have provided you (5)» he said: «Trade».
43 - And Al-Hasan bin Ali informed us, Yahya bin Adam told us, Warqa' told us, from Ibn Abi Najih (6), from Mujahid regarding His saying: {Spend from the good things which you have earned} he said: «From trade» (7).
foot_note:
1. Weak Hadith, narrated with this chain by: Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat (2140) and in Al-Kabir (13/215), Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim in his Fawa'id (78), and others, all from the route of Al-Hasan bin Arafa with it. Abu Hatim said as in Al-Ilal by his son (1172): This Hadith is false, and Qudama is not strong. It has another route narrated by Ahmad (15836), Ibn Abi Shaybah (23422), and Al-Bayhaqi (5/263) from the route of Wa'il bin Dawud, from Said bin Umair, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: Which earning is best? So he mentioned it. Abu Hatim said - as in Al-Ilal (2837) -: The Mursal is more likely. Al-Bayhaqi said: The correct one is the narration of Wa'il from Said bin Umair from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, mursal. Al-Bukhari said: Some attributed it (made it Musnad) and it is an error. See Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir by Al-Bukhari (3/502).
2. Dropped from (Z), established from Berlin and Awqaf copies.
3. In (Z): And Al-Hasan informed us.
4. Established from (Z), and in Original, Berlin and Awqaf: Yahya bin Nafi'. The established is correct, for Yahya bin Adam is famous for knowledge and abundant narration, and he narrated from Warqa' as in Tahdhib al-Kamal. As for Yahya bin Nafi', he is unknown, Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat (7/614), and Al-Mu'allimi commented on him not finding his biography.
5. In Original and (Z): What you earned.
6. In Berlin and Awqaf: Ibn Abi Yahya.
7. Narrated by Ibn Jarir in his Tafsir (4/695).

44 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, Al-Warakani (1) told us, saying Al-Mu'afa bin Imran told us, from Sufyan, from Al-A'mash, from Ibrahim, he said: «It used to be said: The merchant is better than the sitter (one who sits idly).»
45 - Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal informed us, my father, may Allah have mercy on him, told me, Sufyan told us, from Abu Ishaq, he said: «They used to see abundance (wealth) as an aid to religion.» It was said to Sufyan: Did Sufyan Al-Thawri mention it? He said: «Yes.»
46 - Muhammad bin Mahdi bin Ja'far Al-Suri informed us in Tyre, saying: I heard my father say: I was in Tarsus when Al-Ma'mun arrived in Tarsus, and with him were Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him, and Ibn Nuh. He and Ibn Nuh were shackled. He said: So Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him, wrote a note to me: "You know what we are in, and were it not for that, we would have come to you. So if you see fit to come to us, come." So I went to them and narrated to them. Among what Ahmad bin Hanbal, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, wrote from me: Damrah told us, from Raja' bin Abi Salamah, from Abd Rabbih bin Sulaiman bin Zaitun (2), from Ibn Muhayriz, he said: «There is no food with which I fill what is between my sides after my effort, wherein I am counted among the black and the red (everyone), more beloved to me than the food of a truthful merchant.»
47 - And Bishr bin Musa Al-Asadi wrote to me, saying Abdullah bin Salih Al-Ijli told us, saying Isra'il told us, from Abu Hamza, he said: I asked Ibrahim about a man who leaves trade, meaning and turns to deeds (worship) and prayer, meaning
foot_note:
1. He is Muhammad bin Ja'far Abu Imran. See Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil (7/222).
2. In the manuscripts and printed versions: Zanbur, this is an error, and Abd Rabbih has a biography in Tahdhib al-Kamal.

book_title: Encouragement to Trade, Industry, and Work, and Denial of Those Who Claim Reliance (Tawakkul) in Abandoning Work, and the Argument Against Them

text:
and a man who occupies himself with trade, which of them is better? He said: «The honest merchant.»
48 - Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Affan informed us, saying Yahya bin Adam told us, Qais told us, from Abdullah bin Ata, from Abu Ja'far who said: «Ibn Affan was not killed until the revenue of my (1) palm trees reached one hundred thousand.»
49 - Al-Abbas bin Muhammad Al-Duri informed us, I asked him, Ja'far bin Awn told us, Al-A'mash told us, from Salamah (2), from Abu Dhabyan who said: Umar said: «O Abu Dhabyan, (if) (3) acquire wealth» (4).
50 - Ahmad bin Mansur Zaj Al-Marwazi informed us, Al-Nadr bin Shumayl informed us, Shu'ba bin Al-Hajjaj told us, saying: I heard Qatada say: I heard Mutarrif bin Abdullah bin Al-Shikhkhir, from Hakim bin Qais, from Asim, from his father, that he
foot_note:
1. Established from Original (Z). In Kitab al-Kharaj (263) by Yahya bin Adam: (revenue of Ali). In the two printed editions: revenue of his palm trees.
2. In Berlin copy: From Abu Salamah.
3. Addition from (Z).
4. It is in Tarikh Ibn Ma'in narrated by Al-Duri (3/294): I asked Yahya about the Hadith of Al-A'mash from Abu Dhabyan saying: Umar said to me: O Abu Dhabyan, acquire wealth. Yahya said: This is not Abu Dhabyan who narrates from Ali, this is another Abu Dhabyan. In Su'alat Abi Ubaid Al-Ajurri li Abi Dawood (p. 146): I said to Abu Dawood: Al-A'mash from Salamah bin Kuhayl from Abu Dhabyan? He said: «This is not that one, this is a man from Quraysh.» Its chain is weak, Abu Dhabyan Al-Qurashi is unknown. See Al-Mizan (4/542). It has a witness in what Al-Bukhari narrated in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad (576) from Abu Dhabyan - who is Al-Janbi Husayn bin Jundub not the Qurashi mentioned earlier - he said: Umar bin Al-Khattab said to me: O Abu Dhabyan, how much is your stipend? I said: Two thousand five hundred. He said to him: O Abu Dhabyan, acquire from tillage and Sabiyah (livestock reproduction) before the boys of Quraysh rule over you, stipend will not be counted as wealth with them. End quote. He means by it offspring in livestock and their abundance. It is said the family of so-and-so has Sabiyah: i.e. many livestock. The plural is Sawabi, which is originally the membrane in which the fetus comes out. It is said it is the placenta. See Al-Nihayah (2/341).

51 - Harb bin Ismail Al-Kirmani informed us, Bashar bin Musa told us, Abbad told us, Yahya bin Saeed told us, from Said bin Al-Musayyib, he said: «There is no good in one who does not seek money to pay his debt with, protect his honor with, and fulfill his obligations with, and if he dies he leaves it as inheritance for those after him.»

There is no good in one who does not gather money so he pays (4) his debt, and restrains his face (from begging) with it.»
53 - Harb bin Ismail informed us, Abu Ma'n Al-Raqashi told us, Umar bin Dharr informed us, from Mujahid, he said: I heard him say: «If Allah provides one of you with a thousand dirhams, let him not spend it and say: Indeed Allah Almighty will provide for me, but let him seek in it from the bounty of Allah.»

54 - Muhammad bin Ismail informed me, Waki' informed us, from Musa bin Ali bin Rabah Al-Lakhmi, from his father who said: I heard Amr bin Al-Aas say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to me: «O Amr, tighten your clothes and weapons upon you, and come to me.» He said: So I tightened my clothes and weapons upon me, then I came to him and found him performing ablution. He raised his gaze at me and lowered it and said: «O Amr, I want to send you on a mission (face), so Allah Almighty accepts your safety and grants you spoils, and I desire for you a righteous desire regarding wealth.» He said: I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I did not submit (become Muslim) out of desire for wealth, I only submitted out of desire for Jihad and being with you." He said: «O Amr, excellent is the righteous wealth for the righteous man» (1).
55 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Shu'ba, from Al-Hakam, from Mujahid {Spend from the good things which you have earned (2)} he said: «Trade».
56 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' told us, Yunus bin Abi Ishaq told us, from his father, from Abdul Rahman bin Abza who said: «Prophet David, peace be upon him, said: Excellent aid is wealth or affluence for religion» (3).
foot_note:
1. Sahih Hadith, narrated by Ahmad (29/298), Ibn Abi Shaybah (7/557), Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad (299), Ibn Hibban (3211) and others from the route of Musa bin Ali with it. Al-Iraqi authenticated it in Al-Mughni (3253), Al-Albani as in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, and Sheikh Muqbil in Al-Sahih Al-Musnad mimma laysa fi Al-Sahihayn (1006). In some printed copies of the Hadith: «And I give you a good portion (Za'bah) of money» i.e.: I give you a batch of money. The origin of Za'b: pushing and dividing. See Al-Nihayah (2/302).
2. In all copies: What we provided you.
3. Its chain has weakness due to the 'an'anah (narrating with 'from') of Abu Ishaq because he is a Mudallis, although he explicitly stated hearing from Abdul Rahman as in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad (138). The Athar was narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (35267), and Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Islah al-Mal (67) via Waki' with it.

58 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Muhammad bin Sulaym, from Ibn Abi Mulaykah, from Aisha, may Allah Almighty be pleased with her, who said: «Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, was the most trading (merchant) of Quraysh until he entered into the Emirate» (1).
59 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Al-A'mash, from Khaythamah (2) who said: Abu Al-Darda, may Allah be pleased with him, said: «I was a merchant before the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was sent. When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was sent, I wanted to combine trade and worship but it did not straighten out, so I left trade and turned to worship» (3).
foot_note:
1. Sahih Athar, narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (22605) from Waki' from Muhammad bin Sharik, and narrated by Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal in Al-Zuhd for his father (573) from Dawud bin Amr Al-Himsi from Abdul Jabbar bin Al-Ward, both: from Ibn Abi Mulaykah who said: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: And in it that Abu Bakr said: ... I used to be the most trading of Quraysh and the most wealthy of them, but when the Emirate occupied me, I saw that I acquire from wealth according to what occupied me... . And Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated with a Sahih chain (22603) saying: Waki' told us, he said: Al-A'mash told us, from Shaqiq, from Masruq, from Aisha, she said: Abu Bakr said in his illness in which he died: Look at what increased in my wealth since I entered the Caliphate and send it to the Caliph after me, for I used to consider it lawful, and I used to acquire from fat roughly what I used to acquire from trade. Aisha said: When he died we looked, and behold a Nubian slave carrying his children and a camel used for irrigation. She said: So we sent them to Umar. She said: My grandfather informed me that Umar wept and said: May Allah have mercy on Abu Bakr, he has tired those after him severely.
2. In Berlin copy: Shu'ba.

60 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Mis'ar, from Abu [Bahr] (1), from a Sheikh of theirs who said: I saw a coarse lower garment (Izar) on Ali, and he said: «I bought it for five dirhams; whoever gives me a profit of one dirham on it, I will sell it» (2).
61 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Sharik, from Simak bin Harb, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: A caravan (3) arrived in Medina, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, bought from it and profited ounces (of silver). He divided them among the widows of Banu Abdul Muttalib and said: «I do not buy anything for which I do not have the price» (4).
62 - Muhammad informed us, Waki' informed us, from Amr bin Isa Abu Na'ama, Harith bin Al-Rabi' Al-Adawi told us, saying: I heard Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, say: «(Incited) (5) upon you are three travels: Hajj, Umrah, and a man seeking with his wealth in one of these ways. The independent and the charitable - meaning better. By Allah, for me to die in a facet of these facets seeking with my money
foot_note:

In Ahmad and Ibn Al-Athir: He said: And I saw tied dirhams with him, and he said: This is the remainder of our expenses from Yanbu.

4. Weak Hadith, narrated by Ahmad (2093), Abu Dawood (3344), Ibn Abi Shaybah (22190) and others via Waki' with it. Sharik is Saduq (truthful) but has bad memory, and Simak's narration from Ikrimah is confused. Al-Albani weakened it in Al-Da'ifah (4766).
5. In the margin of the Original: This is not from lying (Kadhib), rather this is incitement (Ighra'), meaning stick to these things.

63 - Yahya informed us, Abdul Wahhab told us, Said informed us, from Qatada, from Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: «O people, (incited) (2) upon you - i.e., decreed upon you - is that one of you takes his money and seeks in it from the bounty of Allah Almighty, for in it is worship and charity. By Allah, for me to die in the two branches of my saddle while I seek with my money in the land (3) from the bounty of Allah is more beloved to me than to die on my bed» (4).
64 - Yahya informed us, Abdul Wahhab bin Ata Al-Ijli told us, Said bin Abi Aruba told us, from Qatada bin Di'ama that he said regarding this verse: {O you who have believed, do not consume one another's wealth unjustly but only [in lawful] business by mutual consent} he said: «Trade is a provision from the provision of Allah, lawful from the lawful of Allah for whoever seeks it with its truthfulness and righteousness» (5).
foot_note:
1. Weak Athar, narrated by Abdul Razzaq (5/172), Ibn Abi Shaybah (22187), Abu Ubaid in Gharib al-Hadith (4/148) and others from Harith with it. Harith's condition is unknown, Al-Ijli and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy.
2. In Berlin copy: Confirmed upon you.

4. Weak Athar, containing the 'an'anah of Qatada and he did not meet the senior Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Abdul Razzaq narrated it (11/464) from Ma'mar, from Al-Zuhri, from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah bin Umar, or others, he said: so he mentioned similarly. The correction is from Shu'ab al-Iman (2/450), Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from Ubaidullah from Umar or others, then said: And others narrated it saying: from Umar bin Al-Khattab, he did not doubt, and added: He recited this verse: {And others traveling throughout the land seeking the bounty of Allah}.

65 - Yahya informed us, Abdul Wahhab informed us, Shu'ba informed us, from Al-Hakam bin Utaybah, from Mujahid that he said regarding this verse: {O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned} he said: «From trade» (1).
66 - Yahya told us, Abdul Wahhab informed us, Said informed us, from Qatada who said: «We used to be told that the truthful honest merchant is with the Seven under the shade of the Throne on the Day of Resurrection» (2).
67 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, from Abu Abd Allah, Abdul Razzaq told us, Ma'mar informed us, Hammam bin Munabbih told us, saying: This is what Abu Huraira, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, told us from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: «David used not to eat except from the work of his hand» (3).
68 - And Harb informed me, saying Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman told me, Abu Usama told us, from Hisham bin Urwa, from his father who said: «David used to address the people on his pulpit, then work palm leaves with his hand, and he would make a basket or something from it, then send it with someone to sell it and eat from its price» (4).
69 - Harb informed me, Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, Harun told us, Damrah told us, from Ibn Ata, from his father, who said: «Solomon son of David used to work palm leaves with his hands and eat barley bread» (5).

71 - Harb informed me, Ali bin Uthman told us, Hammad bin Salamah told us, Thabit informed us. And Al-Duri (2) informed us, Arim told us, Hammad bin Salamah told us, from Thabit, from Abu Rafi', from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «Zakariya was a carpenter» (3).

Were it not for this estate I have, kings would have used me as a handkerchief. If you see the reciter sticking to the door of kings; know that he is a thief.

74 - Yazid bin Abdullah Al-Asbahani informed me, Al-Hussein bin Muhammad bin Sinan Al-Makki told us, he said I read to Al-Hussein (1) bin Al-Faraj, saying: Sufyan bin Uyaynah was asked about sustenance (Qut) and what is indispensable, is there an account for it [on Judgment Day]? He said: «No.»
75 - Muhammad bin Ismail informed us, Waki' informed us, from Hammad bin Salamah, from Hisham bin Zaid, from Anas bin Malik, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: «If the Hour rises upon one of you and in his hand is a sapling, let him plant it» (2).
76 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Hazim informed us, that Ishaq bin Mansur told them that he said to Abu Abd Allah the saying of Ali, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him: Four thousand and below is expenses (Nafaqah) and what is above that is Hoarding (Kanz). Ahmad said: «He means it is not appropriate for him to hold more than four thousand.» Ishaq bin Mansur said: Ishaq bin Rahwayh said: «Its meaning is the four thousand he needs.» As if he says: He is not asked about that, so what is above that is Kanz, and Kanz if its Zakat is paid, the name of Kanz leaves it (3).
77 - Muhammad bin Ayyub informed us, Waki' told us, from Sufyan, from Abu Husayn, from Abu Al-Duha, from Ja'dah bin Hubayrah, from Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: «Four thousand and below is expenses, so what is more than that is Kanz» (4).

And in this Chapter is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: «It is sufficient sin for a man to waste those he sustains.»
80 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, saying I heard Abu Abd Allah say: Let the servant fear Allah and not feed them except what is good (pure/halal), meaning the dependents. I said to Abu Abd Allah: A man says: I will not earn until the intention becomes correct for me, and he has dependents. He said: «Since he has [dependents], it is obligatory upon him to keep them chaste, so part of the intention is protecting them» (1).
81 - Muhammad bin Abi Harun informed me, that Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Hani told them, saying I heard Abu Abd Allah being asked about the Hadith of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: «It is sufficient sin for a man to waste those he sustains» (2). He said: «A man has relatives, so he travels and leaves them. If he leaves them alone, are they not wasted while they have no one but him?» I said: Yes. He said: «This is its meaning» (3).
82 - Muhammad bin Abi Harun informed me, that Ishaq told them, saying: Abu Abd Allah was asked about a man who left dependents and young children, and fears they might be wasted, and he has
foot_note:
1. In Sahih Muslim (994): From Abu Qilaba, from Abu Asma, from Thawban, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: The best Dinar a man spends is a Dinar he spends on his dependents, a Dinar a man spends on his riding beast in the cause of Allah, and a Dinar he spends on his companions in the cause of Allah. Abu Abd Allah, saying: A man leaves work or sits, and says: I do not know anyone but an oppressor or usurper, so I take from their hands, and do not aid them, nor strengthen them in their oppression. He said: No one should leave work, and sit waiting for what is in people's hands. I choose work, and work is more beloved to me. If a man sits and does not have a profession, his soul invites him to take from what is in people's hands. If they give him or prevent him, he occupied himself with work (meaning he should occupy himself). And earning is abandoning greed. And he (peace be upon him) said: «For a man to carry a rope and gather wood then sell it in the market, and become independent by it, is better for him than to ask people, whether they give him or prevent him» (1). So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed that work is better than begging. And Allah Almighty said: {Hasten to the remembrance of Allah and leave sale}, so His saying this implies buying and selling. And I choose for the man to move about seeking sustenance, and independence from what is in people's hands, and it is better in my view. I said: There are people here who say: We are Mutawakkilah (Relier's), and we do not see working except with other than oppressors and judges, and that is because I know no one but an oppressor. Abu Abd Allah said: How excellent is reliance on Allah Almighty, but no one should sit and not work anything until this one and that one feeds him. We choose work, and seek provision, and be independent of begging. Independence from people by work is more beloved to me than begging (2).

He said: «So go and buy food (for your family) (1) for five dirhams, and clothing for your family for five.» He said: O Messenger of Allah, Allah has blessed me in what you ordered me. He said: «This is better than coming on the Day of Resurrection with a mark of begging in your face. Indeed, begging is not lawful except for three: For one with agonizing blood money (debt), or horrific debt, or abasing poverty» (2).

2. Weak Hadith, narrated by Ahmad (19/182), Abu Dawood (1641), Ibn Majah (2198) and others via Al-Akhdar bin Ajlan with it. Al-Bukhari said of Abu Bakr Al-Hanafi: His Hadith is not correct. Ibn Qattan Al-Fasi said: His integrity is not established so his condition is unknown. Tahdhib al-Tahdhib (6/88). Al-Albani weakened it in Al-Irwa (867).

Chapter: Comprehensive on Tawakkul for Whoever Uses it With Truthfulness

120 - Abu Bakr Al-Marrudhi informed us, saying: It was said to Abu Abd Allah: What is the truthfulness of reliance on Allah Almighty? He said: «To rely on Allah, and there is no one in his heart from humans whom he hopes will bring him anything. If he is like that, Allah provides for him, and he is relying (Mutawakkil)» (1).
121 - Abu Bakr told us, in another place, he said: I mentioned Tawakkul to Abu Abd Allah, may Allah have mercy on him, so he permitted it for whoever uses truthfulness in it (2).
122 - And Abu Bakr informed us, saying: I asked Abu Abd Allah about a man who sat in his house and says: I sit and adhere to patience in the house, and I do not inform anyone of that, while he is one who sees that he should work. He said: If he went out and worked it would be more beloved to me. If he sits, I fear his sitting will lead him to something else. I said: To what does it lead him? He said: It leads him to expect that something will be sent to him. I said: So if something is sent to him he does not take it. He said: This is good. I said to Abu Abd Allah: A man in Mecca said: I will not eat anything until they feed me (3), and he entered the mountain of Abu Qubais. Two men came to him while he was wrapped in a rag and threw a shirt to him, but he did not wear it. So they took his hands and dressed him in the shirt, and placed something before him but he did not eat, until an iron key was placed

I said to Abu Abd Allah: A man left buying and selling, and committed himself that no gold or silver fall into his hand, and left his houses and did not order anything in them, and he used to walk in the road, so if he saw something thrown, he took from what was cast. Al-Marrudhi said: So I said to the man: What is your proof in this? (I do not see for you) (1) a proof upon it except Abu Mu'awiyah Al-Aswad. The man said: Yes, Uwais Al-Qarni, he used to pass by dunghills and pick up patches. So he confirmed him and said: He was strict on himself. Then he said: Two people came to me asking me about the like of this (2), so he said he passes in the road and finds something like herbs and the like. I said to them: If you engage in a work you expose yourselves (become famous). They said (3): What do we care about fame?
123 - Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Mansur informed me, saying Al-Mazini asked Bishr bin Al-Harith about Tawakkul. He said: «The Mutawakkil does not rely on Allah to be sufficed (4). If this silver settled in the hearts of the Mutawakkilah (5), they would have cried out to Allah in regret and repentance. But the Mutawakkil, sufficiency from Allah Almighty settles in his heart, so he believes Allah Almighty in what He guaranteed.»

Their pebbles are pearls and rubies, and their mountains are gold and silver. They do not plow, nor sow, nor work any work. They have trees at their doors having fruit which is their food, and trees having wide leaves which are their clothes (7).
